Pours yellowish orange with a small white head. Very strong floral aroma with earthy notes and herbs. Tastes like a regular geuze with a lot of floral and herbal notes. Finish is quite sour and dry with hints of fruits and berries. Nice, quite refreshing geuze.

75cl Bottle at DRBM. Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma is sour, weird flowery note of the elderflowers, rhubarb, a bit yuck-like. Flavour is sour, weird fruitiness, weird sourness. Light bodied. Weird beer, didnt like it.
Fresh yeasty and sour apples with some, cereal. Hard to rate. Clear with small white head. (DRbM 2011)
Bottle @ drbm. Aroma fruity dusty juniper, some spice. Flavour is deep and intense sour fruity citrus and spice. Nice.
Bottle at UDRBM. Clear orange pour, thin white head. Aroma is very spicy with strange berries and fruits, offensive. Flavor is sour and spicy. Nice brew.

Bottle. Hazy dark yellow/orange with  medium off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit and strong elderflower. Flavour is malt, medium tart, elderflower, fruit, light barnyard, floral, little citrus and little sour.

Hazy orange with a huge and lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, heavy elderflowers, moderate sour - wood and barnyard. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 141011

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2014 (Bottle, 0.75 l - bottled 15 June 2010, 201101014) Bottle opened quite loud popping sound. The beer poured golden and clear. Its head was quite large, fizzy and white. Aroma had sourness, grapefruit, elderflowerand a little bit of vomit. Palate was medium bodied and fizzy with quite high carbonation. Flavours were sourness, tartness, nettles, straw, wood, hops and bitterness. Aftertaste was sour, tart and mildly bitter. Very tart beer but also tasty and pleasant.(Update to rating, tap at Pikkulintu, 20140920) The beer nettles notes were more pleasant and tart afteraste lasted long and was good.
Draught at the Mikkeller bar.Hazy orange colour.Taste of peach and elderflowers,dry and flowery with dusty mouthfeels,mild sour and well done beer.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar. Copenhagen. Zwanze Day, 17th September 2011.

Aromas of clean, rich elderflowers, funk and tart. It tastes of elderflower cordial. There are sour notes that resembles the ones in a geuze, its overall very funky and tart. Slighty sweet and for me very balanced. The finish is slightly astringent with a long aftertaste of elderflowers.

Poured hazy orange golden color with minimal fizzy white head that diminished slowly with fair lacing. Heavy tart fruit, spice & yeast aroma. Medium to full body with tingly sticky texture and soft carbonation. Moderate to heavy funky fruit flavor with a solid tart fruit & spice finish of moderate to long duration. This is a great lambic.

@ Stone fest , Chez moeder lambic 
Head: creamy, white

75cl bottle. 2010 Vintage. Loud pop and foam almost coming out of bottleneck. Pours hazy yellow with a nice three fingers fingers white head. Little to no lace. Aroma is fresh, refreshing, stunning: green peppers, lemon zest, flowers, grass, earth and funk. Taste is less spicy than aroma and more balanced. Starts with a huge lemony presence, then turning into a mix of flowers, barnyard funk and peppery spiciness. Light acidic presence wrt ordinary Cantillons, more balanced. Not necessairily better for a sour-head like me, but probably more accessible. Aftertaste is lingering spiciness. Body is medium with medium/little carbonation. This one is complex, one-of-a-kind and easy to drink at the same time. A very fine offer from Cantillon. I really hope this will remain long time in the regular lineup.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2011 bottled: 16-05-2011

Draught @ Moeder Lambic, Brussels. Hazy yellow with a small white head. Smells sour and apples. Tastes sour and fruity (again mostly apple). Great carbo, medium body.

rotten eggs, light sour aroma,golden, yellow,cloudy, white foam, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, soft carbonation, long nice grape finish.

Bottle pour at Holy Grale Zwanze 11. Tropical fruit. Big nose and taste of tropical fruit over the subtle taste of lambic. Then the pickle. Giant pickle taste. Very tasty.
From the bottle at Monks. Hazy golden brown with white froth.  Nose of elderberries, green pepper, grass and wet hay.  Taste is candied lemon peel, parsley, earthy funk and bitter plum.  Very cool.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2015 Sampled at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Hazy pale yellow color. Smell light sourness, not much more. From the bottle, then on tap (2005 edition). The elderflowers give the aroma something special. Its like if there was a heaven, and heaven had a garden, and that garden turned into beer. Huge floral herbal spruce nose--I understand where people are getting jalapeno. Aroma isnt too sour. Flavor adds old wood and more sourness. Not too musty, and the sourness tends to be lemony. text: Bottle (75 cl) from Ölbutikken. Clear orange, medium head. Green apple and grapefruit aroma with clear notes of fresh elderflowers and a touch of wood. No appearant horsestable aroma. Dry with a solid acidity, but not of the usual overpowering Cantillon type.

This rating is for a bottle of Zwanze 2009. Tasted on 7/30/11 from a capped and corked 750mL bottle purchased online from Etre Gourmet, bottled 15 June, 2010.  Pours hazy bright orange with a very thick white head that, at first, recedes quickly to rocky lace, and then slowly to uneven lace with a decent collar, leaving a bit of lace along the inside of the glass.  The nose is sour and tart with lemon zest, and has a spicy character that is hard to nail down, perhaps jalapeno, or light mustard seed, and some funky barnyard and vanilla oak.  The flavor is sour and tart with the lemon juice and zest, moving to a hard to describe floral note that almost comes off as green bell pepper or green peppercorn, with the barnyard funk and vanilla oak underlying.  The body is light with very lively, nearly sparkling, carbonation and a long tart, funky, and tannic green bell pepper and vanilla oak finish.

Fresh newly released. Still couple of months old, no sour cabbage in this one. 75 bottle shared at brewery.  Pours slightly hazy golden with explosive white head.  Aroma of a meadow in the summer with wildflowers.  Flavor backs up aroma with slight bitterness and acidity.  Great beer

750mL Zwanze 2009 version from Ma Che Siete. Shared with Travlr, Manuele, and Franco Fratoni. Enjoyed in the presence of beer royalty! Thanks guys! My first Zwanze pours a hazy, glowing, light yellow to orange with a dense, thick, white head. Excellent retention and lace. Incredibly thick head for a lambic. Aroma is bell pepper, fresh yellow bell pepper, sweet orange sorbet, floral hops, light chili pepper, spiced orange peel. Very odd but inviting. Taste is lemon, tart, lavender, herbal, pine, flowers, other oddities. Gets a little too lemon tea heavy for me. Not really funky or lambic like. Very soft. Would like to retry the Mamouche version.

Bottle thanks to Neil who brought this straight from the brewery. Wonderful funk and tart aromas are accompanied by a noticeable added friend in jasmine. It has all the characteristics I love in Cantillon, but I worry that the flower almost overpowers the beauty of the base beer.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2011 Cantillon Zwaanze 2009 - Bottle from bierbistro. Cloudy golden pour with a thick, moussey head. The aroma is awesome. Loaded with horsey funk and a bright lemony citrus back note. Really soft tartness that leans more lactic than anything else. A sort of vague lemony cruet character that seems to combine the aromatics of the elderflowers and the tartness of the base beer. There is a little bit of an unusual almost jalepeno like quality as it starts to warm up. Incredibly unique with a mixture of soft lactic character and sweet fruit/floral spicing. The tartness remains restrained throughout. Incredibly unique.
Bottle shared and courtesy of RoyceH - thank you Sir! Aromas and sips of flowers dominated. Nice.

Thanks to Masterski for bringing this to our big time Chicago tasting.

750 ml bottle into my Narke tulip...Pour is nothing to discuss as this beer is all about the elder flowers. Going in I had no idea what one smelled like, now I know, and I wont be searching them out again. A super strong acidic chilipepperish aroma attacks your nose from the start almost stinging it like a whiff of a strong medication. I can almost visualize waves of the aroma coming off it like its some cartoon characterization..The taste is much of the same, but thankfully its toned down a bit and not nearly as harsh. The astringency is much weaker, especially as your drink it, I guess you almost get used it to. Its certainly a unique flavor, something probably worth trying but one that is just not for me, despite a relatively high score that I give it for its uniqueness and effort.

Bottle (bottled 15 June 2010) shared by alen, thanks! Pours with a clear (first pour) golden body with a huge fluffy white head. Aromas are funky and acidic, peppery, floral and slightly vegital. Nectar as it warms (honeyblossom). Flavors are acidic, funky, light plastic, pepper, floral, fruity, vinous and dandelion. Some tropical fruit notes as it warms. Lively, dry and tart. Well done as always by Cantillon.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 March 2011, bottle split with my wife at the Cantillon tasting room.
A: Bright orange-amber body. Large eggshell white head that forms with each pour from the bottle. Nice retention and spotty lacing.
S: Bright floral aroma that poured out of the bottle as soon as the cork was removed. A bit of lemon-citrus and mild oak. 
T: Again, the floral notes are bold and dominant. A light citrus, mild funk and sourness, and a bit of earthy oak. Not as complex and rich as the nose, but enjoyable nonetheless.
M: Medium to light body. The floral notes have a little bitterness to them. Quite effervescent. Refreshing.
O: Unique and enjoyable, but ultimately not Cantillons top offering.
On tap at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Hazy golden, big lacing head. Complex acidic, lemony and flowery nose. Lemony flavours followed by dry woodiness, ending quite dry. Seriously good.

Bottle at home. Looks great. Beer in the glass very zippy, huge head. Wonderful fruity aroma. Starts mild, soft-fruity with light elder notes. Fruitines gets stronger and stronger. Also the sour notes are increasing. Sour-dry finish, not too woody, still well balanced fruity. Intense fruity aftertaste. Great beer!

Rajustin vaahtoava, kupliva, hieman samea ja väriltään amber olut. Tuoksu on kukkea, kirpeän hedelmäinen ja happamuutta huokuva. Kirpeän makuinen, hedelmäinen ja maanläheinen. courtesy of Laurent Mousson - hazy blond-orange colour with a solid creamy white foam; a robust aroma of basil with notes of elder and gentian below; medium-bodied and fairly acidic, a solid but subtle carbonation; dry and long acidic aftertaste of cheese, old cellar and basil - very impressive
Taster at Cantillon.  Pours hazy yellow.  Strong aroma of flower and spice.  Tart and sour, which a dry finish.

Bottled 75cl. Indefinitely fantastic, incredibly complex and mindblowingly delicious. Interesting basil components throughout. Definitely one of the most incredible beers I have ever had. Keeping this rating short: my drivel wont add anything to this panel ;-)

Bottle 0,75ltr: Slightly hazy golden Lambic thats not so sour as its regular brews from Cantillon. Its kind a fruity and flowery of taste,and quite dry and bitter too. They used elderflower its an good Lambic variation.

A strong hoppy-floral aroma...hard to put my finger on it, suppose its the elder flower, a bit veggie-like, almost like dandelion.  Hazy gold with a slight sudsy white head.  Tart with a veggie-floral flavor...a bit like red bell pepper.  Really a strange flavor, not my favorite from Cantillon.

Thanks to OSCF for sharing! Thanks Todd!  Hazy pour with lively carbonation.  Aroma is full on floral.  Flavor is very unique.  Floral notes, lemon, wheat, and lacto.  Finish is waxy

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2010 Bottle. 2009 Zwanze. Opens with a very minimal pop. The cork was completely crappy and took a lot of work to get out. Slightly hazed yellow straw color with a nice head. The aroma is floral wih a then strong green chili notes and some bread like qualities. The taste is also fairly floral with the chilis making their presence known. Lingering bitterness. Light flower aroma with some pepper - hard to place the exact smell.  Taste is wonderful tart/sour that is light and lemony with perhaps some pepper.   Steady, high carbonation.  I lack the verbiage to give this beer its full due but it is undoubtedly world class.  Amazing stuff.

750ml bottle, labeled as Zwanze 2009 (not Mamouche), consumed at RBWG in March 2010.  A beautifully cloudy, glowing, golden hued body sports a thin, swirly, off-white layer of foam at the head.  A sudsy, micro-spot wash mostly glides down the glass and rejoins the body.  The nose is completely, 100% unique, far different than any other Cantillon product (or that of any other brewery really) that I can recall.  Earthy as can be, the theme here is very peppery and floral, showing strong suggestions of dried elderflowers, moist potting soil, and fresh celery, all wrapped up beautifully with a mildly tart, lemony lambic shroud.  Wow!  Im caught off guard with these scents, and it takes a while to settle in and contemplate it all.  Flavors are considerably more sour, as the buggy wood and sharp lemon acidity take a more aggressive stance.  The fresh vegetal notes again take hold, giving hints of earthy green herbs, spicy flower blossoms, celery, and maybe some green bell pepper.  Ultimately, it is the lemony base lambic that lingers on the finish, though the earth goes a long way too.  The palate seems more on par with the Cantillon standard, as it shows a dry, crisp, and refreshing acidity, with appropriately soft and persistent carbonation that delicately distributes the complexities that this nepenthe proudly features.  This is one in which the written description simply doesnt translate well......you need to try this brew to understand what its all about.

Thanks Blake on bringing this back! Hazy amber pour, nice white head.  Like no other brew Ive ever had, the aroma was full of flowers, like a garden in my nose.  Slightly tart, but really just a rich, flowery, malt.  Taste is flower up front, touch of lemon tart and some funk, leading into flowery middle, and...more flowers at the end.  Awesome brew!

2010 bottle picked up @ Cantillon.  The beer pours to a hazy straw amber colored body with a starch white head and spotted lacing.  The aroma is strongly floral with what I can only assume is elder flowers.  Theres sour gueuze components going on too.  The flavor is sweet floral and sour funk gueuze.  The beer is really, really floral.  Unique and sour.  Carbonated beyond belief.

Thanks to Blake for bringing this over!  Poured hazy peach with a shorter cap of white head. The flavor found tart floral notes upfront, with more floral and fruity character on the middle.. tart and more bitter on the back-end with, guess it, more floral notes.  Medium-bodied and moderately tart on the palate.. the floral character was really interesting.. good stuff!

750ml bottle thanks to Nick3 on BA.  Pours hazy golden with a one-finger white head that leaves thick foam on the beer.  Very floral and spicy aroma, with less typical Cantillon funk than I expected.  Slightly sweet (believe it or not) pale malt with elderflowers (haha like I know what those taste like), lemony and funky with some interesting spices.  Medium-bodied with average carbonation and average acidity.  Good stuff.  Unique for sure.

750ml bottle, capped and corked, from the Cantillon brewery in Brussels. Dated June 15 2010, yes a little young, but Im mobile these days and sadly lack a fine gueuze cellar where I can store these things. Even when pulling the cork off, you see this strange floral pattern on the side of the bottle... then the cork, the cork, smells like some kind of marvellous gueuze mix that you had only smelled in your dreams, sweet dreams, thinking of what the ideal gueuze must taste like. So it pours into a Belgian chalice, huge head, very white, yellow colour as always. The aroma is this unique floral mix of young and old lambics, fermented wheat, sour vegetables. I could smell this for an hour - its gueuze, but its not gueuze, as it has this complex floral mix like youre walking through a northern European garden while drinking gueuze. The taste is a very fine typical gueuze taste with notes of herbs that I cannot identify, but recognize, from the European continent. Mouthfeel is good, but not perfect. This is really wonderful and unique stuff, like drinking a Belgian garden. I intend to buy a cellar just to have a place to store bottles of it.

August 23, 2010 - as Zwanze 2009 - green 750ml bottle shared with blankboy at BeerBistro (in Cantillon tumblers, no less!  no, we didnt steal them ...)  Very hazy gold, bubbly, with a lasting off-white head.  God I love that aroma, which I described as "a 70-year old, well-used horse blanket which had been left for decades in a dry but sunny corner of an old barn (no mothballs either)" - funky dry herbal straw lemon, even fruit, and oh yes, you can smell those wildflowers!  The taste - heaven - while there wasnt much lemon sourness in the floral/funky aroma, its here in the flavour in spades - all the same components, just acidity dominates.  What makes this even more special for me is that the acidity is huge up-front, then fades quickly so that your palate is ready for another hit of it again almost immediately - incredibly drinkable.  Light bodied and sticky, massively acidic of course, strongly carbonated, and the lingering impression is dry floral acidity and a vague suggestion of sweet lemon drops.  This is a great sipper, one of my favorite "drinking" sours of all time, really - the way the carbonation, the funky sourness and the delicate floral character all interact make this one memorable.  I will buy it again - Im so happy this is going into the Cantillon rotation (at least thats what Ive heard).

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2010 Zwanze 2009; Sampled at De Heeren van Liedekercke; July 2010
The beer is lightly hazed in appearance with an orange, pale gold color that is topped by a pale off-white colored head.  This has a wild, peppery aroma to it, a sort of floral, green, almost poisonous smelling somehow, but definitely quite herbal.  There is a hint of plastic character in the nose, it definitely smells of lactic acid and has supporting notes of urea and an earthy, musty mushroom character.  The aroma is very interesting, very intense; the elder-flower is definitely quite dominant in the nose.

The beer tastes sour and lactic up front, but a flower-herbal note starts in the middle and lingers through to the finish.  A woody peppery up front must be contributed by the elder-flowers and is just very, very interesting.  The flower flavor is not nearly as strong as it is in the aroma, which is really a good thing as the aroma is certainly nice and interesting, but the intensity would have been too much if it carried over into the flavor.  Still it is strong enough that it mutes much of the base Lambic flavors.  As my palate adjusts to the elder-flower influence, the characteristic Cantillon flavors become more noticed; urea, mushrooms, an oak character and spiciness as well as a light tannic astringency is found here.  This is light bodied and quaffable, but still has some good texture to it like a good bottle conditioned Lambic should.

This is very, very interesting; while this spice is perhaps a bit too much here, I think it could work quite well in other beers when used with a more restrained hand; the herbal profile is quite distinct and a subtle use in a wit, or even a Rochefort like strong-ale could work very nicely.  I am definitely very happy to have had a chance to try this beer, and to do it at  De Heeren van Liedekercke is definitely quite a treat, when you couple in the great food, atmosphere and proprietors.

Multiple samples at WSF. This stuff was pouring like water. Super bright, juniper, berry aroma, acidic and young, bursting with a unique (for lambic) floral complexity. Nice head on the pour. Flavor of citric acid, rhubarb sourness (I know this is not the rhubarb one), strawberry (yes, it kind of tasted like the pie), with a lovely touch of sweetness at the back that will probably be gone within a few months. A Mes rate. Draught at Moeder Lambic.Utterly beautiful stuff. As the labic fades into the background, youre left with an wonderfully refreshing elderflower aftertaste that has considerable length. Fantastic balance. Typically classy, effortlessly drinkable and yup, Im glad Ive got more. Not one to sit on for sure, the elderflower would not age well but fresh, its bright and alive and an absolute joy to drink. In short: A Cantillong Gueuze with a highly aromatic bouquet of dry flowers
How: Bottle 750ml at at Moeder Lambic Saint-Gilles, Brussels, Belgium.  Consumed when about 1 year of age.
The look: Clear blonde body topped by a medium white head
In long: I am not too familiar with the smell of elder flowers but one thing for sure the aroma of this beer is full of highly aromatic red garden flowers.  So much so that the signature Cantillon funk plays is mostly covered up.  I could actually smell my glass from a few feet away.  This is quite a strong aroma.  Taste is smoother than expected.  Given the strong aroma I expected a punch in the mouth.  Truth is that the taste of a Cantillon Gueuze comes out very strong in this beer.  Stronger than in any other beer from Cantillon, except for the Gueuze of course.  This is like a Cantillon Gueuze with a bouquet of dry flowers.  This beer is replacing the Foufoune as a semi-regular Cantillon.  This is an excellent (like most Cantillon) beer but I prefer the Foufoune which was a real standout in the lineup.  Another big bottle that I drank during my second trip to Belgium.  That was like my 20th lambic in four days.  I was getting to the point where I had a more serious gas leak problem than BP.

Bottle RBWG 10 Cloudy golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Decent retention. The aroma is interesting and tough to peg, but Ill throw hot peppers and celery out there... in a really, really good way. Elder flowers? I dont even know what those smell like. Medium-bodied with a raspy mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Very vegetal, herbal and tart. Finishes bone-dry.

Draught at Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels. Hazy golden with lasting white head. Perfume nose of flowers, wood and spice. Very nice. Tastes great too - the nuance of elderflower works wonders in this beer. A zingy passionfruit like mouthfeel. Low acidic and tart finish. Beautiful beer.

Sample at RBWG.  Pours hazy yellow with a white head.  Nose is funk, jalapenos, cumin, earth, and vinegar.  Flavor is similar with lingering pickled and fresh jalapenos and vinegar.  Interesting beer with the spices included.

Bottle: Poured a dirty yellowish color lambic with a large foamy head with good retention and some very good lacing as well. Aroma is absolutely dominated by elder flowers and is somewhat of an acquired taste. Taste is also dominated by elder flowers and provides a floral and somewhat peppery taste to this beer which is well integrated with the tart and oak from the base lambic. Very refreshing overall though a bit too much flowers for my taste.

On tap at the new Moeder Lambic.  Lovely aroma, really fresh elderflower.  Hazy gold beer with thin white head.  Really good lovely flavours, quite tart on finish, good jicy beer.  Very fresh and refreshing.  Excellent.

Bottle @ The Dome. Golden with off-white head. Strong flowery nose, mingling with citric funky Cantillonesque notes. Elder flowers are noticeably in mouth too, creating a nice contrast between sweet flowery and the peculiar citric and barnyard dry finish.

Bottle split by Shyam.  Thanks yo.  Nose is heavy with light fruit, floral qualities (I assume elder flowers), the light delicate hops of Iris and probably the light vanilla.  Color is a pleasing yellow mellow gold like the above mentioned beers.  Flavor is really interesting: very floral, very rhubarbarous, not super heavy on tart or pepper.  Likely the sweetest lambic of my career.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2012 Several glasses @ Cantillon Quintessence 2012. Boy did I enjoy this beer.
Le bouquet sureau de cette bière est simplement fantastique donnant cette impression de respirer un bon bol de printemps. Tout cela dans un des greniers Cantillon et on a un cadre superbe.
Le palais est tout aussi grandiose avec ce sureau qui est très prononcé mais reste agréable donna t encore une fois ces i,pressions printanières. RBWG10 Old score 7-3-7-3-14; 3/18/2010.
Cloudy golden, thin white head.
Aroma is vinegary, herbal tone, citrus and mild tropical nose.
Flavors, citrus meshed with some underlying acidic/vinegary mouthfeel, crisp finish, floral merigold note.
Would try again.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2010 (750ml bottle,  labeled as Zwanze 2009 )  Pours a lightly hazy yellow body with a small white head.  Aroma of Anaheim chilies, white wine, florals, subtle lemon, and oak.  Flavor of florals, acidic, mild chilies, and some herbs with a dry oak finish.

Thanks to whoever opened this at RBWG. Man this is an odd beer. Nose is strange with an almost asparagus or celery like quality but its not like an infection you can tell from its intensity that its intentional. Its very sour up front, really gives you a nice pucker. The backend smooths out to allow some nice grain flavor and a truly unique spicy celery flavor with a slight hint of berry. I dunno what an elder flower is but man its strange. This is totally unique and awesome in its own right.

Thank you whoever popped this at RBWG. Ryan maybe? Pours a light yellow with bubbly white head. Aroma is very floral, veggies, green pepper, black pepper, lactic acid, funk. Flavor is overwhelming green pepper. Fresh cut green bell pepper. Black pepper, fresh cut flowers, grass, veggies. Strange. The bell pepper flavor didnt do it for me.

Bottle shared by yespr at Woodshop 5.0 (2/20/10): Pours a transparent bright yellow golden with a small ring of white bubbles.  Very unique floral spiced nose with some underlying funk and lemon tartness.  Starts with a soft lemon citrus and herbal bitterness from the elderflowers with a smooth semi-tart finish.  An enjoyable, veey well-balanced, and unique brew.

A: The pour is hazy yellow in color with perhaps some golden tints. Theres a short lived white head, as well.

S: The nose is incredibly interesting, not like any other beer Ive come across. This, of course, would be the Elder Flowers. They provide a strong floral and herbal aroma and something that I can only describe as spicy, along the lines of chiles. Unlike other Cantillon beers, this one isnt overly funky or tart in the nose.

T: The Elder flower flavor is just as intense as the aroma is. The herbal quality is again, extremely strong. The spiciness is not as pronounced, and allows the acidity and tartness to come through a bit more. There is also a slight saltiness which I wasnt expecting, but it added an interesting dimension.

M: The body is fairly standard for a lambic, a bit on the lighter side of medium with a nice tingly carbonation and a dry finish.

D: This was indeed one of the more interesting beers Ive ever had. And in this case, interesting wasnt a polite way of saying "not very good". I enjoyed this experience and hope to have other years of the Zwanze beers.

Hazy orange beer with small whitish rim. Wokked, stirfried, near-fresh vegetables, celery, peppery, citrus flower. Citrus, flowery, delicate springblossoms as flavours. Medium bodied, clean palate, very faint acidburn. This is out of this world; unique! Jean, grand bravo!! If this is  "zwanze", Im going to joke every day from now!

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2011 Bottled, thanks mybestfriend!  Cloudy golden, minimal head. Pungent elderflower aroma. The initial floral sweetness is immediately replaced by citric acidity. Tart, spritzy and fresh, strikingly sour. The lemony horseblanket is evident, yet elderflower comes to dominate. One of the most different Cantillons out there.

Courtesy of YesprCloudy blond color, small creamy head. The elderflower is evident, it has a fat aroma, blending well with a timid sourness. The mouthfeel is very aggressive, it has an immediate, strong citrusy acidity, with pleasant shades of elderflower. Quite fresh, the cellar and cobwebs character of the Lambic is very subdued. Wonderful.

Thanks to yespr for bringing this to Woodshop 5.0.

Tart, fruity, complex, tasty, this is one fine beer.

Woodshop, thanks jespr! Wow.  Pours a cloudy yellowish color with a whitish head.  Aroma is all over the place.  Herbal and floral.  Sweet and sour.  Woody? Vegetal?  Minerals?  Honey.  THe elder flowers really are amazing.  The flavor is sour but so floral and fragrant on the tongue(if that makes sense), earthy funk with lemons, wheat and honey.  Wow.  Just wow.

750mL bottle at Woodshop 5.0, courtesy of yespr. Thanks, Jesper! Pours a hazy yellow color; tiny-bubbled white head with solid lacing; very bright, attractive pour. Hugely grassy, herbal nose; seemingly dry-hopped and very aromatic; hugely funky, tart lemons and barnyard notes; damn lovely aroma on this. Medium body: loads of intense funk, hints of a wheatiness and lots of lemon custard and barnyard character; very sessionable, and not nearly as acidic or sour as many other Cantillon offerings; a hugely funky presence overall. Medium finish: funk, lemons, and hints of wheat.

Thanks to Yespr for sharing this rarity.  Super strange nose greets you...somewhat chemically edge to the lime peel, fresh air, white pepper oddness.  The beer pours a light peach color with thin head.  Flavors to me seemed very vividly like oro blanco grapefruit devoid of any bitterness and most of the tartness...this was coming from the elder flowers no doubt, but it really had a grapefruit-like character in my opinion.  Also noted in the flavors were hints of freshly chlorined pool water.  Very odd beer yet very fun to drink and ponder its complexities.

Thank you Jesper!!!  first, incredible to see him again 2.5 years after RBSG San Diego, shared at Woodshop 5.0!  Pours orange with a tan ring.  Nose is sweet and lightly tart.  Taste is tart fruity, with a huge punch of carbonation, like a really amazing champagne mouth feel.

fogdog rocks!

A:  Pours a nice shade of hazy golden yellow.  Nice foamy head, little retention and no lace.

S:  Very unique aromas.  Very floral.  I dont know what an elder flower smells like but I assume that is what I am picking up.  There is also a strange mix of herbs and rubber behind the first floral burst.  Light citrus round things out.

T:  Whoa, very strange.  There is a strong floral flavor (once again I assume Elder Flower) with a big blast of dill.  Light citrus, salt..... saltine crackers dare I say?  The sourness was very light, even more so by Cantillon standards.  Lots going on here, and the flavors dont seem to mesh.

M:  Medium in body, smooth, a bit dry in the finish.

D:  Not the most drinkable.  Unique and one of a kind for sure.
Roses salt sour . Tangy very floral. Sea flavors. This is very strange and delicious. Acessible. Animal decay. Loveeely

(Bottle, thanks mybestfriend!) Pours hazy deep golden with a white head. The aroma holds perfumey elder flowers up front. Cheesy and barnyard-like notes blendes well with the elder flowers. The typical Cantillon lemon citric tones are quite subtle on the nose. Some cracker-like wheat alongside a whisper of wood. Dusty and spicy. The flavour is light sweet to dry and medium acidic with almost no bitterness. Tones of elder flowers, lemon, wood, brett and lacto. The mouthfeel is surprisingly round and oily with a light to medium carbonation. The finish is dry and citric with perfumed tones of elder flowers lingering. Medium bodied. A beer that is extremely fun to drink!

Bottle from kappldav123, thanks! Blonde, hazy. Flowery honeish citrusaroma. Citrus flavor with pineapple and yoghurt. Sourish with flowery and honey notes. Lovely lambic, but the elderflowers werent really necessary.

The elder flower brings a rather big sweetness to the beer. Refreshing but could do with alittle time, a tad too much elder flower right now and too little funk. Still a impressive beer though.

Hazy orange with a medium white head. Aroma had loads of elderflowers, funk and and wood. Sourish flavour with plenty of fresh elderflowers, barnyard, brett and woody notes. sourish dry fiinish. Thanks yespr.

Hazy golden coloured with a medium sized white head.
Perfumed aroma of elderflowers with notes of lactic acid.
Fruity and light acidic flavour of lactic acid, elder flowers, brett and wood.
Tart finish.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Earth, elder, wood, leather, barn in the aroma. flavour of spice, earth, sourness, grape. Full bodied. Very dry. Sour and fruity end. Very very nice.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a cloudy golden with a lively off-white head. Tart aroma with distinct elderflower accents and barnyard accents. From Cantillon on brewing day, pours a hazy yellow with a nice white head.  Aromas are wonderfull, the strong soft flowers feels very fresh.  The flavors are typical Cantillon, natural sourness and oak and slightly fruity and flowers taste.  You can really feel there are no artifitial products here, and you can truly taste the nature.  A very dry finish.
A very different and pleasant beer.

2 bottles at Le Poechenellekelder sept/oct 2009. & 3 in my cellar!. This is perhaps my favourite beer ever. It needs at least 30 min open before drinking. (The brewer even recommended 24 hours!) Beautiful bouquet of elder flower. Very little head but great colour. It has that great Cantillon sourness, full with the flavour of elderflower. A nice long finish.
It was bottled in May 2009 and it really needed a few months to develop.(Cantillon make it for the open day on Nov 7). I hope it will only get better with time.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2012 [9/8/09] Bottle at Le Poechenellekelder in Brussels. Slightly hazy orange color with a big white head that disappears quickly and leaves only a slim film of white foam. Aroma is spicy with powerful elderflowers and wood - hard to detect anything beyond that. Sour flavor with lots of flowery spiciness, some vinegar notes, oak,  and a dry, somewhat herbal, finish. Medium-bodied. Good, but way too young at the moment and the elderflower is still too dominant.

Draft (pressurized) at Chez Moeder Lambic in Brussels. Lovely orange beer, hazy, with a lovely layer of orange-tinted bubbles sticking around. Nose full of sour citrus: orange, tangerine, limes, grapefruit. Although sour it is quite soft and drinkable. Pretty dry on the finish, very light bitterness. Didnt find the pleasant floral notes until the aftertaste. Absolutely terrific, looking forward to trying it by other means.
